subject: Re: [junit] Is it really neccessery to use Junit with some kind of IDE ?
msgSnippet: ... Guys, use whatever works for you. I usually work with either one test, that for the object that I m working on, or I run the whole automated build. The
messageBody:
On 12/9/05, Rob Sanheim <rsanheim@...> wrote:
> On 12/9/05, David Saff <saff@...> wrote:
> > Simon Chappell wrote:
> >
> > Simon,
> >
> > I'm intrigued. On many of my projects, I have a single suite of fast
> > tests that cover all the classes in my project; no need for a suite for
> > each class. I find that this often allows me to catch accidental
> > dependencies, and also allows me to have the structure of my tests not
> > be rigidly isomorphic to the structure of my code. Would this strategy
> > work on your projects?
> >
> > David Saff
> >
>
> This is similiar to my experience. I have a TestAll that dynamically
> finds all test cases and assembles the suite, no hand coded suites
> needed. There are some tests in there that are slower and could
> (should) probably be moved to a seperater, longer build - it just
> hasn't gotten painful enough for me to do it.
>
> Also, to respond to "I think that working on one object and one test
> at a time is enough". I find that doesn't really work when you want
> to do larger automated refactorings - ie rename class/public
> method/etc. With a fast running local test suites, those types of
> changes are easy and simple. Not sure how well that would work out
> when you have to wait for the build to run to test it.

Guys, use whatever works for you. I usually work with either one test,
that for the object that I'm working on, or I run the whole automated
build. The last big system that I worked on took about a minute and a
half to run the entire build. I find that I really don't feel a need
for anything between those two approaches.

Simon
